`npx tailwindcss <arguments...> --watch`

Issues.Title: fix(corePlugins): more browser compatibility for rtl/ltr
Issues.Body:
I'd like to propose an improvement to the `rtl/ltr` core plugin that addresses compatibility issues on certain browsers and devices.

**Current Issue:**

The existing implementation uses the `:where` CSS selector to achieve bidirectionality support. While this approach offers certain advantages, it has limited browser compatibility, particularly on iPhone devices before September 2020. This can cause layout and rendering problems for users on these browsers.

**Proposed Solution:**

I propose replacing the `:where` selector with the `[dir="ltr"]` selector. This alternative:

- Offers broader browser compatibility, ensuring that the plugin functions correctly on all major browsers and devices, including older iPhones.
- Maintains the desired functionality of providing LTR/RTL support.
- Is generally considered a more widely supported and reliable approach for achieving bidirectionality.

**Benefits:**

By adopting this change, we can:

- **Improve user experience** for a wider range of users by ensuring consistent plugin functionality across different browsers and devices.
- **Reduce potential bugs and support issues** related to browser compatibility.
- **Align with standard practices** for achieving bidirectionality in CSS.

**Testing:**

I have thoroughly tested this change on various browsers and devices.  
These tests confirm that the `[dir="rtl"]` selector functions as expected and addresses the compatibility issues associated with `:where`.

**Request:**

I kindly request that you review my proposed change and consider merging this pull request to improve the plugin's compatibility and user experience. I am confident that this modification will have a positive impact on the project and its users.

Thank you for your time and consideration.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(corePlugins): more browser compatibility for rtl/ltr" (#12895)

Issues.Title: Add `mix-blend-plus-darker` utility
Issues.Body:
This PR adds 'plus-darker' support to mix-blend-mode.

One PR already added 'mix-blend-plus-lighter' (#8288) , but there should also be 'mix-blend-plus-darker' since blend mode also has a 'plus-darker' value that could be added last time. 

[mix-blend-mode on MDN lists all possible values](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/mix-blend-mode)

From what I know, it seems only Safari supports `plus-darker` at the moment since this style is used heavily in macOS's vibrant visual style.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Add `mix-blend-plus-darker` utility" (#12923)

Issues.Title: CLI does not work with `--watch` when daemonized
Issues.Body:

v18.18.2

N/A

Linux

**Reproduction URL**

N/A (this is a bug in the CLI, not the generated CSS)

**Describe your issue**

Running the following bash script does not result in Tailwind rebuilding when files are changed:

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash
```

Issues.Title: Sort arbitrary properties alphabetically across multiple class lists
Issues.Body:
Fixes https://github.com/tailwindlabs/prettier-plugin-tailwindcss/issues/246

In Tailwind we sort classes alphabetically before processing to produce a deterministic order. And, when we encounter an arbitrary property we register it _at that time_ so that's the order it'll take when sorting. In most cases this is fine because we sort up front, however, in the Prettier plugin we don't know all classes up front ‚Äî each individual class list is sorted separately but uses the same internal context for performance reasons. This means that we need to do some extra bookkeeping to ensure they're sorted consistently regardless of the order of individual class lists or files scanned.

This PR does this bookkeeping and will sort classes to ensure that the arbitrary properties are always alphabetical when handled by the prettier plugin even scross separate class lists or files.

Now given these two files, a.jsx and b.jsx:

```jsx
// a.jsx
export default function ComponentA() {
  return <div className="[--fg:#fff]" />
}
```

```jsx
// b.jsx
export default function ComponentB() {
  return <div className="[--bg:#111] [--bg_hover:#000] [--fg:#fff]" />
}
```

If you format each individual one with prettier or format all of them at one time the order of the properties will no longer flip-flop between these two lists:
```
[--bg:#111] [--bg_hover:#000] [--fg:#fff]
```

```
[--fg:#fff] [--bg:#111] [--bg_hover:#000]
```

Issues.Title: Bug with Custom Selector and Styling Based on Sibling State Using peer Not Working
Issues.Body:
# Bug Report: Custom Selector and Styling Based on Sibling State Not Working ## Description I've encountered an issue when setting a custom selector in the Tailwind CSS configuration and applying styling based on sibling state. According to the Tailwind CSS documentation on [Configuration - Selector Strategy](https://tailwindcss.com/docs/configuration#selector-strategy), I set a custom selector in my Tailwind configuration as follows: ```javascript module.exports = { // Other configurations... important: '#app', }; ``` However, when attempting to apply styling based on sibling state as described in the documentation section on [Styling Based on Sibling State](https://tailwindcss.com/docs/hover-focus-and-other-states#styling-based-on-sibling-state), using the `peer` class does not work as expected. ### Example HTML structure ```html

I am visible if input gets focus

``` ### Expected Behavior The paragraph (`

`) tag should become visible when the `` element (marked with the `peer` class) receives focus, as per the Tailwind CSS `peer-focus` utility. ### Actual Behavior The `peer-focus` utility does not apply, and the paragraph remains hidden regardless of the `` element's focus state. ## Steps to Reproduce 1. Set a custom selector in the Tailwind CSS configuration using the `important` property. 2. Apply the `peer` class to an input element and the `peer-focus:block` utility to a sibling element. 3. Focus on the input element and observe that the sibling element's visibility does not change as expected. This issue suggests that there might be a conflict or a bug when using a custom selector in combination with the `peer` utility for styling based on sibling state.

**Describe your issue**

`content` configurations returned from tailwind plugins are not respected for excluded file globs.
D.h. the classes in the [file](https://github.com/frontline-hq/tw-exclude-content/blob/main/src/lib/file.tdc.ts#L1) should not be included in the css as specified [here](https://github.com/frontline-hq/tw-exclude-content/blob/main/tailwind.config.js#L10-L11)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Exclude files from tailwind parsing by plugin" (#12896)

Issues.Title: Group hover leaks when applying to SVG defs
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**Tailwind CSS version:** v3.2.4

**Framework:** Next.js 13.0.0

**Node.js version:** v20.3.0

**Browser:** Chrome, Firefox

**Operating System:** Windows

**Reproduction URL:** https://play.tailwindcss.com/hkfzY1h86v

**Describe your issue**

When using group hover with SVG defs (in my example a `<stop>` inside `<linearGradient>`, but it doesnt work in `<linearGradient>` itself too), the group causes a leak, in which every svg in the page is affected, and only the first hover works.

In my example there are 3 group divs each inside of a different flex container where the behaviour i just explained, happens.

It also breaks if they are on a grid, which was my initial use case that triggered this bug, i just removed the grid in the reproduction to display that the bug is not related to what container the groups are in.

Using [Named Groups](https://tailwindcss.com/docs/hover-focus-and-other-states#differentiating-nested-groups) also results in the same buggy outcome.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Group hover leaks when applying to SVG defs" (#12876)
